required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy of Extended Release Tramadol for Treating Prescription Opioid Withdrawal
clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy of Extended Release Tramadol for Treating Prescription Opioid Withdrawal

brief_summary.textblock: Prescription opioid addiction is a growing public health problem and more pharmacologic treatments are needed because current approved medications have had limited patient acceptance (naltrexone), limited availability (methadone), and concerns about misuse and diversion (methadone and buprenorphine). Tramadol is a currently approved medication used to treat moderate-severe pain, and initial studies demonstrate that it may be useful for treatment of the uncomfortable syndrome of opioid withdrawal without producing euphoric effects. This study will determine whether two different doses of extended release tramadol can treat opioid withdrawal and whether tramadol itself produces withdrawal after it is no longer taken.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Subjective Opioid Withdrawal Total Adjective Score
primary_outcome.description: range of scores is 0-84; low scores indicate no opioid withdrawal, higher scores indicating more opioid withdrawal present. T

primary_outcome.measure: Total Number of Breakthrough Withdrawal Medication Doses Taken Week 1
primary_outcome.description: There were four medications (acetaminophen for aches/pains, zolpidem for trouble sleeping, bismuth subsalicylate for diarrhea, and alumina/magnesia/simethicone for nausea/upset stomach) available to all volunteers in all treatment arms to help relieve any withdrawal symptoms that were not relieved by the blinded tramadol/placebo doses.

primary_outcome.measure: Subjective Opioid Withdrawal Adjective Total Score Week 2
primary_outcome.description: range of scores is 0-84; low scores indicate no opioid withdrawal, higher scores indicating more opioid withdrawal present

primary_outcome.measure: Total Number of Breakthrough Withdrawal Medication Doses Taken Week 2
primary_outcome.description: There were four medications (acetaminophen for aches/pains, zolpidem for trouble sleeping, bismuth subsalicylate for diarrhea, and alumina/magnesia/simethicone for nausea/upset stomach) available to all volunteers in all treatment arms to help relieve any withdrawal symptoms that were not relieved by the blinded tramadol/placebo doses.

arm_group.description: Tramadol 200 mg daily for 1 week then placebo given for 1 week
Tramadol 600 mg daily given for 1 week given then placebo given for 1 week

intervention.other_name: Placebo is like a sugar pill

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Addicted to opioids
Exclusion Criteria:
- Any major medical or psychiatric disorder that would be contraindicated for participation

results_reference.citation: Lofwall MR, Babalonis S, Nuzzo PA, Siegel A, Campbell C, Walsh SL. Efficacy of extended-release tramadol for treatment of prescription opioid withdrawal: a two-phase randomized controlled trial. Drug Alcohol Depend. 2013 Nov 1;133(1):188-97. doi: 10.1016/j.drugalcdep.2013.05.010. Epub 2013 Jun 4.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Outpatient screening. Recruitment by advertisement and word or mouth.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Persons screening who did not meet inclusion/ exclusion criteria were not enrolled. Persons who did not complete the study were not included in analyses. The study was designed as an efficacy study that a priori stated it would enroll until 12 persons in each group completed the study and analyse only completers. No serious AEs in noncompleters.

group.title: Tramadol 200 mg Daily
group.description: Medication: Extended release tramadol 200 mg daily given for 1 week then placebo given for 1 week

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo given for two weeks

group.title: Tramadol 600 mg Daily
group.description: Medication: Extended release tramadol 600 mg daily given for 1 week followed by 1 week of placebo dosing.

baseline.population: The study was a priori defined to evaluate only completers. There were 12 completers in each of the three study arms. We retained the description of the completers because it corresponds to the primary outcomes results that are reported (and this is what was proposed a priori and approved by NIDA review).

group.title: Tramadol 200 mg
group.description: Medication: Extended release tramadol for 1 week and then placebo given for 1 week

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Medication: Placebo given for two weeks

group.title: Tramadol 600 mg
group.description: Medication: Extended release tramadol 600 mg given for 1 week and then placebo given for 1 week

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Subjective Opioid Withdrawal Total Adjective Score
outcome.description: range of scores is 0-84; low scores indicate no opioid withdrawal, higher scores indicating more opioid withdrawal present. T
outcome.population: The primary analysis was ANOVA with day and treatment arm as factors. The outcome measure described below is the mean across the days listed.

outcome.title: Total Number of Breakthrough Withdrawal Medication Doses Taken Week 1
outcome.description: There were four medications (acetaminophen for aches/pains, zolpidem for trouble sleeping, bismuth subsalicylate for diarrhea, and alumina/magnesia/simethicone for nausea/upset stomach) available to all volunteers in all treatment arms to help relieve any withdrawal symptoms that were not relieved by the blinded tramadol/placebo doses.
outcome.population: These are data from week 1 -- the 12 people who completed this week in each group. This is the analysis that was specified at the start of the study. The primary analysis was ANOVA with day and treatment arm as factors. The outcome measure described below is the mean across the days listed.

reported_events.desc: There were no serious adverse events for anyone enrolled (completers and non-completers). The remaining adverse events are reported from both completers and non-completers.

group.title: Tramadol 200 mg
group.description: Medication: Extended release tramadol 200 mg daily for one week followed by placebo for one week

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Medication: Placebo for 2 weeks

group.title: Tramadol 600 mg
group.description: Medication: Extended release tramadol 600 mg daily for one week followed by placebo for one week

event.description: Pre-existing condition -- pain due to old MVA whereby shoulder was hurt. Occurred in a non-completer.
Cracked right front tooth prior to admission to study - now with mild pain in that tooth. Occurred in a non-completer.
right sided flank pain that started 2 days prior to randomization, mild severity, occurs when twisting body. Occurred in a non-completer.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: The study was designed to analyze only completers (12 subjects per group so the description of study participant characteristics and outcomes are from these a prior defined n=36 (12 per group) completers.

point_of_contact.organization: University of Kentucky College of Medicine
